posts.author: Theophilus Fist
posts.content:
Why Monk 2/BG 3?

Monk 1/ BG 4 gives you d6 Sneak Attack at the cost of a worthless (for you) Deflect Arrows. You defer 4 AC until later, but you pick up d6 damage (in the rare event you end up meleeing).

Monk 3/BG 2 gives you Monk Speed & Still Mind and the cost of a worthless (for you) Turn Undead.  With your high saves, Still Mind basically gives you mind affecting immunity.  Monk Speed and Expeditious retreat will make you wickedly fast.

posts.author: Kalistez

Am I better off playing as a full caster and dropping the armour and autostill feats in exchange for more Great Charisma's, or should I go for more Blackguard levels to give a greater melee presence ?

EMA gives +20 AC. MA gives +1 AC. Haste gives +4 AC, (enough to cap the dodge AC bonus). Cat's will also add +2 to AC.
Dark blessing adds +10 to +13 to all saves. You get Evasion from monk.
There are 46 skillpoints leftover to spend as you please.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Most PW's have disabled the Expertise/Improved Expertise modes while casting so obviously the answer is that you don't really need them except if you plan to melee a lot, a properly modified Tenser's Transformation (like in WoG) would definitely let you do that. But you can always melee while buffed the normal mobs saving spells for the big monsters, kinda like "melee mage" does, that is always a good option especially if it is difficult to assemble a proper team and you have to solo most of the time. In that case however i have to question the use of Divine Shield here, let's see...

EMA (5), MA (1), Boots (6), Haste (4), that's already 16 points of AC coming from the Dodge type, so DS will get you at most another 4 AC since the cap is at twenty. Maybe you should consider DM instead, that will add the whole ammount to your attacks (up to 16 divine damage). The AC of this Sorcerer will most likely be over 70/72 in a +5/+6 module like the North, and if you need more defense for Bosses you can cast Bigby's V for +10 AC.

By the way, nice build Mick.

Sorcerer's are so over the top, so powerful that most of the times i play them, i just roll with them without any specific plan and still destroy every opposition wiith ease. To have a build like this back me up, is amazing. I am sure you will do fine Kalistez no matter what the final version will be.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
If you want to play a sorcerer for the first time, focusing on spellcasting is the way to go, if nothing else, just for the experience of playing a spellslinger.
If Expetise is disabled while casting, there is no point in taking the feats. If it is not disabled, the expetise feats are very good.
Valerfor has a point when questioning the usefulness of DS. It boils down to what items are available. In a low magic setting DS is great, but if +6 items are available DS or EMA are worth reconsidering since you will reach the cap when dodge AC is 20.
Kalistez, the way you move PA and DS to pre epic is fine in that they free up two epic feats for G Cha. I think you qualify for Auto still I at level 24 and can finish with Autostill III at level 27.
I am not a fan of multiclassing sorcerers too early since that slows down the build-up of spellpower. Aiming at BG3 at level 18 is necessary for a pre epic DS. I would wait with Monk1 until level 15 to get level 7 spells before multiclassing. Normally I would wait until I have level 9 spells, but you can't do that here. BG at level 18 enables 21 ranks in Discipline and paves the way for Epic skill focus.
You also ask about two G Cha vs Armor skin and a summon. I would take the G Cha route almost every time unless the summons are beefed up considerably.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: I agree with Mick, 2 Great CHA > +2 AC & Summon.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
You have covered the essentials so what feats to take next depends on the environment where you play, what is available on items, and how you play your caster. Different builders/ playes will probably give different advice.
Another spell focus is definitely an option as long as you know what attack spells you will be using.
Toughness has most to offer the d4 classes with their low hitpoints
Craft wand is another option. If you can recharge wands, you can build up and keep quite a selection of wands with low level spells you have unlearnt.
Skill-focus discipline is also an option since there are quite a few levels between skilldumps and the epic focus comes rather late.

If you are going to fight tough high level bosses with a high SR while your character still is of low level, the spell penetration feats can be helpful. This can happen if you go to high level areas on a PW. This is especially true when you lag 3-4 caster levels behind your character level in pre epic levels. The Breach spells and Mord reduce SR, and often that will be enough to help you out. At higher levls, your caster level becomes so high that this should not be a problem. What you choose to do probably depends on where you play and how aggressively you grind for xp.
